Top-3 Scripts:
so_27149772: $ echo "MAC evbyminsd58df" | sed 's/ .*//'
MAC

$ echo "MAC evbyminsd58df" | cut -d" " -f1
MAC

$ read a _ <<< "MAC evbyminsd58df"
$ echo "$a"
MAC

$ echo "MAC evbyminsd58df" | { read a _; echo "$a"; }
MAC

so_35287738: $ echo 'hello world' | grep -o hello
hello

$ echo "hello world" | sed 's/.*\(hello\).*/\1/'

ul_39039: Get text-file word occurrence count of all words & print output sorted
Top-3 Scripts:
so_35287738: grep --help

$ echo 'hello world' | grep -o hello
hello

so_10113283: cat <yourfile> | grep ".html" | head -n1

cat <yourfile> | grep -A1 "<url>" | head -n2 | tail -n1

cat <yourfile> | grep -o "<url>[^<]*</url>" | head -n1 | cut -d'>' -f2 | cut -d'<' -f1

cat <yourfile> | grep -o "<url>[^<]*</url>" | head -n1 | sed -E -e"s#<url>(.*)</url>#\1#"

ul_39039: echo "Lorem ipsum dolor sit sit amet et cetera." | tr '[:space:]' '[\n*]' | grep -v "^\s*$" | sort | uniq -c | sort -bnr

grep -v "^\s*$"

Explanations about Options.-v: Invert the sense of matching, to select non-matching lines.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.
